page.title: 18THE BELLS OF ABERDYFI
page.content: Aberdyfi's chief claim to musical fame is the well known song Clychau Aberdyfi{(The Bells Of Aberdyfi). Composed by Charles Dibdin 1745-1814,the song is said to be based on a local legend telling of the submerging of the 'Cantrir Gmaelod' or the 'Lowland Hundred' a rich and fertile plain to the west of Aberdyfi and now beneath the waters of Cardigan Bay. Remains of boundaries belonging to this lost land are said to correspond to the submerged reefs which extend into the sea just north of Towyn and south of Borth.Both reefs are well known to local shipping and their extremities are marked by buoys.The remains of tree stumps said to be from forests long since submerged can still be seen around the Dyfi estuary at very low tides.
